title: How difficult is it to synthesize the nerve agent Novichok? And who, apart from Russia, might have the capacity to do so? - Quora

response.answer_text: there is no such thing as “the nerve agent Novichok” Novichok is the name given to a series of nerve agents. Novichok means “ newcomer “ in Russian.A Novichok agent is characterised by generally being a type of binary chemical agent. A binary agent is one which exists in two components; ( precursors) each one being of low ( or lesser)toxicity , but which when mixed, become very powerful. This makes them easier to transport; and when unmixed, difficult to detect . They were also intended to circumvent the chemical weapons bans, since the two precursor elements were not, themselves, banned elements. ( this loophole has now been largely closed)Novichoks are also chemically much faster acting than more “ conventional “ nerve agents, due to the chemical bonding structure they employ. This makes them much harder to treat; as time to introduce counter agents to the body is much reduced, and the countering agents ( which are, themselves, quite toxic) have to be used in greater doses.There are many “Novichok” agents, but it is believed that only 5 have been successfully weaponised. They have also been reported as being inspection and pesticides.The currently known ones are typical VX style of agents, being organophosphate acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. In simple terms they inhibit a key enzyme which is vital to nerve functioning; this results in failure of nerves, loss of motor response, paralysis and heart/breathing failure.Novichoks are fast acting, and much more powerful ( up to 8 times) than “ standard “ nerve agents such as VX . Hence LD50 ( lethal dose ) is much lower.The high power, and difficulty in detecting the precursors, made Novichoks good Clandestine weapons; as the quantity needed is smallTo answer “difficulty to synthesise”; once you know the formulas , then chemically, it is similar to the synthesis of any other nerve agent or pesticide. The “ trick” is knowing the proportions of the two precursors; and the way of mixing them. Because the precursors themselves are much less toxic, then clandestine manufacturing could required much less safety precautions than conventional agents, providing that the precursors are kept completely separate.Note; I have deliberately left out some more technical aspects of this answer, as I have no wish to publish in public, dangerous details of these agents. Other parts are deliberately vague. If you are an organic chemist, you will know ( or can find) more details

It is true that it isn’t necessarily that difficult to synthesize Novichok agents — many chemists would have that capability. What is actually rather difficult is purifying and weaponizing such an agent. According to analysis, the agent used was rather pure. It is one thing to synthesize a highly toxic compound, but figuring out how to purify it without killing yourself would be exceedingly difficult. This process would require producing multiple batches and developing a suitable workup that removes unwanted side-products as well as remaining traces of reagents and reactants…a process that would require a very well-funded laboratory. Even after you figure out how to purify the agent, you would then have to figure out how to weaponize it. Since this is reportedly a binary weapon, procedures and equipment have to be devised allowing the two precursors to be combined immediately prior to use. For example, if the binary precursors can be prepared in liquid form then they could be stored in two seperate aerosol containers and then sprayed on a surface to produce the toxin. However, getting such a process to work is exceedingly difficult. The agent needs to be dispersed in a manner so that it sticks to the surface — if it drips off then it will not work. On the other hand, if it dries too fast than the victim may not retain a sufficient amount of the toxin on their hands. Here there are many minute details to work out — how to stabilize the solutions in the containers, how to prepare the solutions to keep the nozzle from clogging, what is the best solvent and concentration, what type of metal can be used to store the material, are additional chemicals required to stabilize the precursors, etc). Working out all of these details would require a detailed and quite expensive effort. So while there is potentially a large pool of chemists who could synthesize a toxin like Novichok, there is a much smaller pool of people that could actually weaponize it. It would also be a time-consuming and expensive process, requiring specialists from multiple areas of expertise (engineering, chemistry, fabrication, industrial production).
